title: Complex conjugate
summary: In mathematics, the complex conjugate of a complex number is the number with an equal real part and an imaginary part equal in magnitude but opposite in sign. That is, (if a {\displaystyle a} and b {\displaystyle b} are real, then) the complex conjugate of a + b i {\displaystyle a+bi} is equal to a − b i . {\displaystyle a-bi.} The complex conjugate of z {\displaystyle z} is often denoted as z ¯ {\displaystyle {\overline {z}}} or z ∗ {\displaystyle z^{*}} .
